title: Pandemic Preparedness Fatigue
context: After COVID-19 killed millions and cost the global economy trillions, the world vowed 'never again.' Governments created pandemic preparedness offices, funded surveillance systems, and stockpiled supplies. But institutional memory is short and budgets are competitive. Within 3 years of the pandemic's acute phase, preparedness funding was being cut, surveillance systems defunded, and stockpiles allowed to expire. The pattern is well-documented: after every major pandemic (1918 flu, 2003 SARS, 2009 H1N1, 2014 Ebola), the world invests in preparedness, then defunds it when the threat feels distant. COVID-19 was supposed to be different because of its unprecedented scale. It wasn't. The preparedness infrastructure built in 2020-2022 is already eroding, and the next pandemic — which epidemiologists consider a certainty — will find us less prepared than we were in 2019.
hypothesis: COVID-19 permanently improved global pandemic preparedness and response capabilities.

chain.root: Invest heavily in pandemic preparedness after COVID-19

effects.label: Preparedness funding gets cut as pandemic memory fades
effects.impact: US pandemic preparedness office budget cut 30% by 2025

children.label: Competing budget priorities (defense, infrastructure) crowd out preparedness
Politicians can't justify spending on threats that aren't visible
Preparedness is prevention — and prevention never gets credit because nothing happens

effects.label: Surveillance systems degrade without sustained investment
effects.impact: Wastewater surveillance programs defunded in multiple states

children.label: Early warning systems require continuous operation, not just crisis activation
Trained personnel leave for stable jobs when funding becomes uncertain

effects.label: Public trust in health institutions eroded by pandemic response
effects.impact: Trust in CDC dropped from 69% to 44% (2020-2024)

children.label: Politicization of public health measures reduces compliance in future pandemics
Vaccine hesitancy increased — not just for COVID but for all vaccines
Misinformation infrastructure built during COVID persists and grows

effects.label: Stockpiles expire and aren't replenished
effects.impact: Strategic National Stockpile PPE expiring without replacement

children.label: Ventilators, PPE, and antivirals have shelf lives — stockpiling is ongoing, not one-time
Domestic manufacturing capacity built during COVID shutting down as demand drops

dontIf: You're cutting pandemic preparedness funding because 'COVID is over'
Your preparedness plan assumes the next pandemic will look like the last one
ifYouMust: Fund preparedness as permanent infrastructure, not crisis response — like fire departments, not fire sales
Automate stockpile rotation so supplies are used before expiration and continuously replenished
Maintain surveillance systems during inter-pandemic periods — they're useless if activated only during crises
Rebuild public trust through transparency and depoliticization of public health guidance

alternatives.name: Dual-use health infrastructure
alternatives.note: Build systems that provide value during non-pandemic times (general disease surveillance, hospital capacity)

alternatives.name: International pandemic treaty
alternatives.note: Binding international commitments to maintain preparedness regardless of domestic political cycles

alternatives.name: Private sector preparedness requirements
alternatives.note: Require large employers to maintain pandemic response plans and supplies as a condition of operation
